Quote: Most of life is so dull that there is nothing to be said about it, and the books and talk that would describe it as interesting are obliged to exaggerate, in the hope of justifying their own existence.
Author: E. M. Forster

Quote: That is the one unforgivable sin in any society. Be different and be damned!
Author: Margaret Mitchell

Quote: Six months ago I had never been to England, and, certainly, I had never sounded the depths of an English heart. I had known the shallows.
Author: Ford Madox Ford

Quote: The whole mad swirl of everything that was to come began then.
Author: Jack Kerouac

Quote: In his Petersburg world, all people were divided into two completely opposite sorts. One was the inferior sort: the banal, stupid and, above all, ridiculous people who believed that one husband should live with one wife, whom he has married in a church, that a girl should be innocent, a woman modest, a man manly, temperate and firm, that one should raise children, earn one’s bread, pay one’s debts, and other such stupidities. This was an old-fashioned and ridiculous sort of people. But there was another sort of people, the real ones, to which they all belonged, and for whom one had, above all, to be elegant, handsome, magnanimous, bold, gay, to give oneself to every passion without blushing and laugh at everything else.
Author: Leo Tolstoy

Quote: I prefer unlucky things. Luck is vulgar. Who wants what luck would bring? I don’t.
Author: D. H. Lawrence

Quote: Human speech is like a cracked kettle on which we tap crude rhythms for bears to dance to, while we long to make music that will melt the stars.
Author: Gustave Flaubert

Quote: They looked at each other, baffled, in love and hate.
Author: William Golding

Quote: I never liked to hunt, you know. There was always the danger of having a horse fall on you.
Author: Ernest Hemingway

Quote: “Begin at the beginning,” the King said gravely, “and go on till you come to the end: then stop.”
Author: Lewis Carroll

Quote: I do suspect that he is not really necessary to my happiness.
Author: Jane Austen

Quote: You can’t breathe dead hippo waking, sleeping, and eating, and at the same time keep your precarious grip on existence.
Author: Joseph Conrad

Quote: Time, which sees all things, has found you out.
Author: Sophocles

Quote: They were women who idolized their children, worshiped their husbands, and esteemed it a holy privilege to efface themselves as individuals and grow wings as ministering angels.
Author: Kate Chopin

Quote: I don’t exactly know what I mean by that, but I mean it.
Author: J. D. Salinger

Quote: It was curious to think that the sky was the same for everybody, in Eurasia or Eastasia as well as here. And the people under the sky were also very much the same—everywhere, all over the world, hundreds or thousands of millions of people just like this, people ignorant of one another’s existence, held apart by walls of hatred and lies, and yet almost exactly the same—people who had never learned to think but who were storing up in their hearts and bellies and muscles the power that would one day overturn the world.
Author: George Orwell

Quote: Ever’body’s askin’ that. “What we comin’ to?” Seems to me we don’t never come to nothin’. Always on the way.
Author: John Steinbeck

Quote: The Mole was a good listener, and Toad, with no one to check his statements or to criticize in an unfriendly spirit, rather let himself go. Indeed, much that he related belonged more properly to the category of what-might-have-happened-had-I-only-thought-of-it-in-time-instead-of-ten-minutes-afterwards.
Author: Kenneth Grahame

Quote: It’s a dangerous business, Frodo, going out of your door.
Author: J. R. R. Tolkien

Quote: Like so many Americans, she was trying to construct a life that made sense from things she found in gift shops.
Author: Kurt Vonnegut

Quote: Beware; for I am fearless, and therefore powerful.
Author: Mary Shelley

Quote: And they beat. The women for having known them and no more, no more; the children for having been them but never again. They killed a boss so often and so completely they had to bring him back to life to pulp him one more time. Tasting hot mealcake among pine trees, they beat it away. Singing love songs to Mr. Death, they smashed his head. More than the rest, they killed the flirt whom folks called Life for leading them on.
Author: Toni Morrison

Quote: I saw within Its depth how It conceives
Author: Dante Alighieri

Quote: All things in a single volume bound by Love
Author: Virginia Woolf

Quote: of which the universe is the scattered leaves.
Author: Albert Camus

Quote: And again she felt alone in the presence of her old antagonist, life.
Author: James Joyce
Book: A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man

Quote: It was like knocking four quick times on the door of unhappiness.
Author: Jane Austen

Quote: A certain pride, a certain awe, withheld him from offering to God even one prayer at night, though he knew it was in God’s power to take away his life while he slept and hurl his soul hellward ere he could beg for mercy.
Author: Charlotte Brontë

Quote: Laugh as much as you choose, but you will not laugh me out of my opinion.
Author: Franz Kafka

Quote: I ask you to pass through life at my side—to be my second self, and best earthly companion.
Author: Virginia Woolf

Quote: It is an essential part of the justice dispensed here that you should be condemned not only in innocence but also in ignorance.
Author: Geoffrey Chaucer

Quote: The world wavered and quivered and threatened to burst into flames.
Author: Jack London

Quote: Who then may trust the dice, at Fortune’s throw?
Author: Mark Twain

Quote: When, on the still cold nights, he pointed his nose at a star and howled long and wolf-like, it was his ancestors, dead and dust, pointing nose at star and howling down through the centuries and through him. And his cadences were their cadences, the cadences which voiced their woe and what to them was the meaning of the stillness, and the cold, and dark.
Author: Zora Neale Hurston

Quote: I was a-trembling, because I’d got to decide, forever, betwixt two things, and I knowed it.
Author: F. Scott Fitzgerald

Quote: There are years that ask questions and years that answer.
Author: Pierre Choderlos de Laclos

Quote: And so with the sunshine and the great bursts of leaves growing on the trees, just as things grow in fast movies, I had that familiar conviction that life was beginning over again with the summer.
Author: Charles Dickens

Quote: I assure you that the world is not so amusing as we imagined.
Author: William Shakespeare

Quote: Ask no questions and you’ll be told no lies.
Author: Aldous Huxley

Quote: I will wear him
Author: Nathaniel Hawthorne

Quote: In my heart’s core, ay, in my heart of heart.
Author: George Eliot

Quote: Lying in bed, he would think of Heaven and London.
Author: Emily Brontë

Quote: It is a curious subject of observation and inquiry, whether hatred and love be not the same thing at the bottom.
Author: William Faulkner

Quote: For years after Lydgate remembered the impression produced in him by this involuntary appeal—this cry from soul to soul, without other consciousness than their moving with kindred natures in the same embroiled medium, the same troublous fitfully-illuminated life.
Author: Edith Wharton

Quote: Whatever souls are made of, his and mine are the same.
Author: Virgil

Quote: The air brightened, the running shadow patches were now the obverse, and it seemed to him that the fact that the day was clearing was another cunning stroke on the part of the foe, the fresh battle toward which he was carrying ancient wounds.
Author: William Makepeace Thackeray

Quote:
“Do you know—I hardly remembered you?”
“Hardly remembered me?”
“I mean: how shall I explain? I—it’s always so. Each time you happen to me all over again.”
Author: Doris Lessing

Quote: In his deepest heart there surge tremendous shame and madness mixed with sorrow and love whipped on by frenzy and a courage aware of its own worth.
Author: Ralph Ellison

Quote: So, with their usual sense of justice, ladies argue that because a woman is handsome, therefore she is a fool. O ladies, ladies! there are some of you who are neither handsome nor wise.
Author: Harper Lee

Quote: I was filled with such a dangerous delicious intoxication that I could have walked straight off the steps into the air, climbing on the strength of my own drunkenness into the stars. And the intoxication, as I knew even then, was the recklessness of infinite possibility, of danger, the secret ugly frightening pulse of war itself, of the death that we all wanted, for each other and for ourselves.
Author: Gabriel García Márquez

Quote: As I made my way home, I thought Jem and I would get grown but there wasn’t much else for us to learn, except possibly algebra.
Author: Virgil

Quote: Both of them remained floating in an empty universe where the only everyday and eternal reality was love.
Author: Jane Austen

Quote: For now the seventh summer carries you,
Author: Kurt Vonnegut

Quote: A wanderer, across the lands and waters.
Author: D. H. Lawrence

Quote: You are never to stir out of doors till you can prove that you have spent ten minutes of every day in a rational manner.
Author: Edith Wharton

Quote: I have this disease late at night sometimes, involving alcohol and the telephone.
Author: Doris Lessing

Quote: Do come back and draw the ferrets, they are the most lovely noble darlings in the world.
Author: Jack Kerouac

Quote: Once more it was borne in on him that marriage was not the safe anchorage he had been taught to think, but an uncharted voyage on the seas.
Author: Margaret Mitchell

Quote: Time is the River on which the leaves of our thoughts are carried into oblivion.
Author: Gabriel García Márquez

Quote: I told Terry I was leaving. She had been thinking about it all night and was resigned to it. Emotionlessly she kissed me in the vineyard and walked off down the row. We turned at a dozen paces, for love is a duel, and looked at each other for the last time.
Author: Mark Twain

Quote: Babies, babies, babies. Why did God make so many babies? But no, God didn’t make them. Stupid people made them.
Author: George Eliot

Quote: Her heart of compressed ash, which had resisted the most telling blows of daily reality without strain, fell apart with the first waves of nostalgia.
Author: Geoffrey Chaucer

Quote: Jim said that bees won’t sting idiots, but I didn’t believe that, because I tried them lots of times myself and they wouldn’t sting me.
Author: Dante Alighieri
